Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 3: The Bodhisattva notices the five marks

It is at this juncture that the bodhisattva Svetaketu, sweeping with his glance Jambudvipa, the Land of the Plum-rose Trees, noticed the five special features there: [the future mother’s] Caste, Country, Era, Ancestry, and [the specific] Woman.
Scene working notes: The canonical passage refers merely to the "bodhisattva" with no mention of "Svetaketu" (dam pa tog dkar po)

Sun of Faith - English: He saw a family, an exceptionally noble and well-respected one, belonging to the warrior caste.
He noted the excellent location, a splendid fortress-town situated in the Central Lands of Magadha.

Reflecting on the era, he realized that it was one lost in the mists of despair and deep gloom, but not yet totally obscured by the five degeneracies—these were times wherein human life lasted on the average a hundred years.
Then he examined more closely the Maha-sammata (Mang po bkur ba) line of descent and found it faultless over seven generations on both the paternal and maternal sides.
Finally, his glance rested upon a woman: a mother unblemished by the imperfections of femininity—
a woman who was endowed with every possible superiority
and above all, had accumulated enough merit to carry a bodhisattva in her womb for a period of ten moons—
a woman who had paid homage to past Conqueror Buddhas (rgyal ba) before formulating the wish to become a buddha's mother.
The Bodhisattva recognized that all of the most promising qualities graced Princess Mahamaya-devi.
Hence he addressed the gods of the six divine orders sojourning in Tushita, and also those who dwelt in the other realms of the worlds of desire, and repeated thrice the following words:
“The time is now right. I must leave Tushita, take rebirth as the son of King Shuddhodana and thus gather the nectar of realization.
Those among you who hope to share this ambrosia with me would do well to take rebirth in some human family of Madhyadesha (Yul dbus).”
“O Bodhisattva, give us a hearing!” Tushita's gods implored.

Sun of Faith - English: In Jambudvipa, even the 18 great masters—the six sophistic teachers of dialectics (rtog ge ba drug), the six [Brahmins], who repeated [the incantations?] (rjes su sgrog pa), and the the six masters of nihilist meditation (snyoms ‘jug pa drug) have been unable to still this turmoil.
Moreover, we are going to set up a Dharma Throne, one twelve leagues high, for you here in Tushita.
It will be more beneficial, Master, to stay among us and teach the Dharma!”
“My friends,” the Bodhisattva responded, “let us play all our instruments of music together.”
And while wondrous sounds filled the air, the Bodhisattva blew into a conch.
Inscription - English: Svetaketu blows a conch and the gods play musical instruments

Sun of Faith - English: “Which instrument rang out loudest of all?”
“The conch shell.”
“Just as the conch's sound soared above all the other instruments, so the teaching that I am going to impart will surpass the eighteen philosophers' mere word-wars.
The nectar of my realization will quench the thirst of all beings.
One lion is enough to subjugate many animals;
a single diamond can cut through all other stones;
the god Indra, he on his own, defeats numerous titan-chiefs;
one sun dispels the myriad shades of night.
Those among you who hope to attain the highest realization must immediately incarnate in one of the six main cities of Jambudvipa.”
Straightaway the news spread among all the gods of all space: before twelve years have elapsed, the Bodhisattva will enter the womb of his noble mother.
At that period of time, nearly five hundred self-originated buddhas lived near Jambu-dvipa.
Scene working notes: The story here of the 500 Pratyeka-Buddhas does not occur in the main passage of the Vinayavastu from which the rest of this chapter seems to be drawn. It does, however match almost verbatim the brief accounts provided in the Lalitavistara (see below) and in the Kangyur dkar chag of both the Lhasa edition (TBRC #W26071: vol. 100, 109b.7-110a.1) and the dpe bsdur ma edition (TBRC #W1PD96682: vol. 107, p. 206). Although both of these editions of the Kangyur post-date Tarantha's work by over 300 years, they are based on earlier editions for which there does not seem to be text-searchable versions (i.e., Narthang). Here is the passage from the dkar chag in its entirety: "de'i tshe 'dzam bu'i gling na rang sangs rgyas lnga brgya tsam gnas pa rnams phan tshun du 'dus te wa ra Na sir byon/ da ste sangs rgyas myur du 'byon pas bdag cag gis 'gro ba'i don bya mi dgos so snyam ste phung po lhag med kyi dbyings su 'das/". [It is also worthwhile to note that references to the Buddha in Tuṣhita as the Bodhisattva Svetaketu occurs in the narrative right after this passage.]. Here is the account in the Lalitavistara: "de'i tshe yul wā ra ṇā si'i ri dwags kyi nags drang srong ltung ba na rang sangs rgyas lnga brgya 'khod pa de dag gis kyang sgra de thos nas nam mkha' la shing ta la bdun srid du gyen du 'phags nas me'i khams la snyoms par zhugs te sgron ma bzhin du yongs su mya ngan las 'das so/" (Lhasa Kangyur, vol. 48, 20a.5-20a.6)

Sun of Faith - English: Of one accord, they gathered together at Benares.
Aware that the Buddha would not be long in coming into our world and that thus, their efforts on behalf of sentient beings would no longer be necessary,
they passed into space beyond suffering, leaving no trace of temselves.
Inscription - English: Five hundred Pratyekabuddhas miraculously pass beyond suffering
